title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one effect that acid deposition has on trees in a forest ecosystem, such as any of the following:

· Leaves and needles turn brown or yellow.

· Leaves and needles fall off the tree.

· Tree growth is slowed.

· Seed production/the reproductive rate of trees may decrease.

title: Part B(iii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not explain how the results of the experiment would change if the soil sample used contained higher concentrations of limestone, such as any of the following:

· Soils with higher concentrations of limestone (calcite) will buffer acid deposition more than soils with lower concentrations of limestone.

· Limestone will prevent the pH MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaqGWbGaaeisaaaa@37D4@ of the soil sample from decreasing as much or as quickly.

· Soils formed from limestone can neutralize acid rain, so a higher concentration of limestone in soils will decrease the effects of acid rain.

· If the soil has limestone, the pH MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaqGWbGaaeisaaaa@37D4@ of the soil will not decrease as much or decrease as quickly as soils without limestone.

title: Part C(iii)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe how a pollutant that is released from the combustion of coal contributes to the formation of acid deposition at coal-fired power plants, such as any of the following:

· Nitrogen oxides ( NO x MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaqGobGaae4ta8aadaWgaaWcbaWdbiaabIhaa8aabeaaaaa@390E@ ) react with water in the atmosphere to form nitric acid.

· Sulfur dioxide ( SO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaqGtbGaae4ta8aadaWgaaWcbaWdbiaaikdaa8aabeaaaaa@38D4@ ) reacts with water in the atmosphere to form sulfuric acid.

· Sulfur dioxide ( SO 2 MathType@MTEF@5@5@+= feaagKart1ev2aaatCvAUfeBSjuyZL2yd9gzLbvyNv2CaerbuLwBLn hiov2DGi1BTfMBaeXatLxBI9gBaerbd9wDYLwzYbItLDharqqtubsr 4rNCHbGeaGqiVu0Je9sqqrpepC0xbbL8F4rqqrFfpeea0xe9Lq=Jc9 vqaqpepm0xbba9pwe9Q8fs0=yqaqpepae9pg0FirpepeKkFr0xfr=x fr=xb9adbaqaaeGaciGaaiaabeqaamaabaabaaGcbaaeaaaaaaaaa8 qacaqGtbGaae4ta8aadaWgaaWcbaWdbiaaikdaa8aabeaaaaa@38D4@ ) reacts with water in the atmosphere to form sulfuric acid.

title: Part C(v)
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not explain how the data in the graph supports the hypothesis that the combustion of coal in coal-fired power plants could be correlated to the damage in the red spruce forests by stating that based on the data in the graph, coal use has been decreasing since 2001, thus decreasing emissions that contribute to acid deposition. With less sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide emissions, less acid deposition is produced (as seen by the decrease in acidity in the rainwater), leading the red spruce forests to recover.

The response explains how the data in the graph supports the hypothesis that the combustion of coal in coal-fired power plants could be correlated to the damage in the red spruce forests by stating that based on the data in the graph, coal use has been decreasing since 2001, thus decreasing emissions that contribute to acid deposition. With less sulfur dioxide and nitrogen oxide emissions, less acid deposition is produced (as seen by the decrease in acidity in the rainwater), leading the red spruce forests to recover.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not identify another source (other than the combustion of coal in power plants) of the gases that can cause the acid deposition affecting the forests, such as any of the following:

· Combustion of fossil fuels from motor vehicles

· Combustion of fossil fuels for manufacturing and industry

· Burning of biomass

· Volcanic eruptions
